newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU still unable to agree on base area penalties.
newsitem.headline: EU still unable to agree on base area penalties.

text.p: European Union member states are still unable to agree on a proposal to make penalties for exceeding planting limits on cereals and oilseeds more flexible, a Dutch Presidency spokesman said on Thursday.

Germany, France and Italy continue to demand a change allowing penalties to be targeted on those regions which exceed the limits but this is not acceptable to the European Commission, the official told a news briefing.
The presidency will not ask for a decision at next week's farm ministers meeting.
"We are not pressing for a decision. It will be a question of seeing how the Council feels. There is still a lot of opposition," the official said.
Germany has said that it wants to be able to target penalties because former east German states have been penalised for overplanting in western Germany.
Lack of agreement means that farmers are faced with national penalties and no special exceptions for countries such as Spain which are vulnerable to drought.

The proposal was sent back for further study by farm ministers in December when a Commisison spokesman said that the changes being demanded by Germany and other member states would weaken the 1992 reform of the Common Agricultural Policy and make the system too complex.
